page.title: 11LANDSCAPE OF MARSKE AREA.
page.content: Marske lies in a South facing hollow surrounded by beautiful woodlands in a landscape that is rich in variety. The houses are close together on two levels with the Church a little lower, and the distant view is of the green slopes of Downholme topped by a fringe of trees and the sharp edge of a steep scar. A low wooded hill behind the Village gives shelter and below are ornamental gardens of Marske Hall and farmland that undulates gently towards the river Swale. From the North East the Marske Beck flows through the valley with a prominent limestone cliff rising sheer to pasture and moorland, and the cottages of Clints nestle against the conifers that cling to it's rocky outcrop. A 16th century bridge with ribbed arches crosses the beck below the Village. Here the road starts to climb towards Marrick.
